title: Acoustic Telemetry
text:
Acoustic telemetry, simply, is the use of sound to track aquatic animals through water!



Graphic representation of how acoustic telemetry works. An acoustic receiver will detect a signal from an acoustic transmitter implanted inside the walleye.

title: Acoustic Telemetry
text:
Acoustic telemetry, simply, is the use of sound to track aquatic animals through water!



Graphic representation of how acoustic telemetry works. An acoustic receiver will detect a signal from an acoustic transmitter implanted inside the walleye.

title: Acoustic Telemetry
text:
Acoustic Transmitters
Acoustic transmitters are small tags we surgically implant into the belly cavity of the walleye. Every 60-120 seconds, there’s a signal we call a “ping” that is transmitted out into the water column, and if it’s passing by a receiver, will be logged and used later to track the path of the fish. These transmitters will last for a total of two years.
Pretty cool, right?







This is what the acoustic transmitters look like.

title: Acoustic Telemetry
text:
How we achieve this
To achieve this, we use acoustic receivers for long term, continuous tracking of aquatic animals! Since the receivers are always on, they are constantly recording temperature and signals from acoustic transmitters that are implanted within the walleye.







This is an acoustic receiver.

title: Acoustic Telemetry
section: How will I know if I’ve caught a fish part of this study?
text:
How will I know if I’ve caught a fish part of this study?
Wonderful question! All walleye that are tagged will have an orange loop tag between its first and second dorsal fin (see below)! This tag will have a phone number and loop tag number on it, so when you call it in, we can quickly identify the walleye!







Walleye photo credits to the Wisconsin Cooperative Fishery Research Unit (WCFRU)

title: How Can You Help?
text:
As an angler, you can provide some very useful information for my project! Our goal is to assist TWRA in understanding movements and habitat use of walleye in the reservoir, and provide information that can be useful to improving stocking practices for the species.



Photo credit to the Wisconsin Fishery Cooperative Research Unit (WFCRU)




If you capture a walleye that has a loop tag, this is what you can do to help contribute to the project (and get your photo on this website as an acknowledgement)!



Try to keep the walleye alive. This is critical because we encourage you to release the fish once you’ve contacted us!



Call myself (Brittnany) first, and if you are not able to reach me for any reason then you can call TWRA, but I will be the first point of contact! We will have a series of questions for you such as general capture location, length, and weight of the walleye you caught!
If for any reason the walleye is dead or if you have to harvest it, no problem! We still ask that you remove the acoustic transmitter that is located in the belly of the fish and return it to the university. These are expensive pieces of equipment, and we would like to get them back! These tags will also have sensors on them that we need to download, so getting them back is a huge help to the project. It is also helpful for me to know the fate of the fish!
Snap a photo of the loop tag, which will have my phone number on it so you can refer to it later!



Snap a photo with your catch and email it to us! We want to see some pearly whites and anglers having fun fishing!



We would greatly appreciate it if you would consider releasing your walleye. The longer these tagged fish are swimming around in Watts Bar, the more information we can get, providing TWRA with information that can help continue to improve the walleye fishery! Please leave the loop tag attached to the fish when you release it, as it will be used to identify the fish again later!

title: Third Blog Post
text:
The source for any page in your website could also be a Jupyter Notebook. This one is third-post/index.ipynb.
Here’s an example I borrowed from the Seaborn docs:

import seaborn as sns

sns.set_theme(style="whitegrid")

# Load the diamonds dataset
diamonds = sns.load_dataset("diamonds")

# Plot the distribution of clarity ratings, conditional on carat
sns.displot(
    data=diamonds,
    x="carat", hue="cut",
    kind="kde", height=4, aspect=1.5,
    multiple="fill", clip=(0, None),
    palette="ch:rot=-.25,hue=1,light=.75",   
)

title: Acknowledgements
text:
I want to start off by thanking my advisor, Dr. Lisa Izzo, who has been a great mentor throughout my graduate career. I also want to thank my lab mates for their help throughout this project!
I would like to thank the Herbert College of Agriculture and School of Natural Resources in which a large portion of my funding originates!





I would also like to thank TWRA for their collaboration and assistance in field work and expanding my project! Special thanks to Joey Root and Mike Jolley for their endless knowledge of Watts Bar Reservoir and their excitement for the project!





Thank you to Innovasea, our vendor we purchase a large portion of our gear from and their assistance in the field!





Last, but not least, I would like to thank you, the public for your support and collaboration during this project!

title: FAQ
text:
The loop tag is an external indicator the individual is part of the study. They do not hinder the fish’s ability to swim or carry on normal activities post surgery. They’re extensively used in mark/recapture studies, where these studies are used for population statistics. In my case, this will be useful for you, the angler, to accurately identify a walleye tied to my study.
These tags are also incredibly useful to determine what proportion of the population is recaptured and where. For instance, if the Emory River is heavily fished due to increased accessibility or popularity by anglers, versus the Clinch River, which might not be as heavily populated with walleye anglers, then I expect more calls about fish coming from the Emory River.



This study will last about a year and a half! I would like to capture movement during two spawning periods: Spring 2025 and Spring 2026, which will help indicate if walleye have a preference of spawning grounds within Watts Bar Reservoir and its tributaries!



If an angler catches a walleye and it is deemed not fit to return to the reservoir, you can call me and I will instruct you on how to take out the transmitter and the address to send it to. Once I receive the transmitter in the mail, the angler will receive a $100 reward.
However, if an angler calls in a captured walleye and release it back into the reservoir, the angler’s name will be entered in a lottery for the chance to win a $200 reward at the end of the study.



The walleye are supplied with a constant steady flow of water over their gills during surgery, so they are stable during the surgery.

text:
The loop tag is an external indicator the individual is part of the study. They do not hinder the fish’s ability to swim or carry on normal activities post surgery. They’re extensively used in mark/recapture studies, where these studies are used for population statistics. In my case, this will be useful for you, the angler, to accurately identify a walleye tied to my study.
These tags are also incredibly useful to determine what proportion of the population is recaptured and where. For instance, if the Emory River is heavily fished due to increased accessibility or popularity by anglers, versus the Clinch River, which might not be as heavily populated with walleye anglers, then I expect more calls about fish coming from the Emory River.



This study will last about a year and a half! I would like to capture movement during two spawning periods: Spring 2025 and Spring 2026, which will help indicate if walleye have a preference of spawning grounds within Watts Bar Reservoir and its tributaries!



If an angler catches a walleye and it is deemed not fit to return to the reservoir, you can call me and I will instruct you on how to take out the transmitter and the address to send it to. Once I receive the transmitter in the mail, the angler will receive a $100 reward.
However, if an angler calls in a captured walleye and release it back into the reservoir, the angler’s name will be entered in a lottery for the chance to win a $200 reward at the end of the study.



The walleye are supplied with a constant steady flow of water over their gills during surgery, so they are stable during the surgery.

title: Watts Bar Walleye
text:
If you love walleye fishing, you have a great opportunity to contribute to a meaningful research project that will help guide TWRA management of walleye moving forward!
Between the 1980’s - 2011, the Tennessee Wildlife Resources Agency (TWRA) were stocking sauger, a popular sportfish amongst anglers. However, due to inconsistent and unpredictable spawning success, TWRA made the decision to change their stocking practices to stocking walleye.
This is where my project comes in! In partnership with TWRA (shoutout to Mike Jolley and Joey Root of Region 3), we will be deploying passive acoustic receivers throughout Watts Bar Reservoir, and surgically implanting acoustic transmitters into walleye to start tracking their movements throughout the reservoir!

title: Watts Bar Walleye
text:
If you love walleye fishing, you have a great opportunity to contribute to a meaningful research project that will help guide TWRA management of walleye moving forward!
Between the 1980’s - 2011, the Tennessee Wildlife Resources Agency (TWRA) were stocking sauger, a popular sportfish amongst anglers. However, due to inconsistent and unpredictable spawning success, TWRA made the decision to change their stocking practices to stocking walleye.
This is where my project comes in! In partnership with TWRA (shoutout to Mike Jolley and Joey Root of Region 3), we will be deploying passive acoustic receivers throughout Watts Bar Reservoir, and surgically implanting acoustic transmitters into walleye to start tracking their movements throughout the reservoir!

title: Watts Bar Walleye
text:
About Me
I’m a first year graduate student at the University of Tennessee - Knoxville, under the advisement of Dr. Lisa Izzo. Part of the School of Natural Resources, I’m obtaining my M.S. in fisheries science! My project will be documenting habitat use and spawning in walleye (Sander vitreus) in Watts Bar Reservoir.

title: Watts Bar Walleye
text:
Education
M.S. Fisheries Science, University of Tennessee - Knoxville | Knoxville, TN | August 2024 - Present
B.S. Marine Biology, College of Charleston | Charleston, SC | 2016 - 2020

title: Acoustic Telemetry
text: Acoustic telemetry, simply, is the use of sound to track aquatic animals through water!

title: Acoustic Telemetry
text: Acoustic telemetry, simply, is the use of sound to track aquatic animals through water!

title: Acoustic Telemetry
text:
Acoustic Transmitters
Acoustic transmitters are small tags we surgically implant into the belly cavity of the walleye. Every 60-120 seconds, there’s a signal we call a “ping” that is transmitted out into the water column, and if it’s passing by a receiver, will be logged and used later to track the path of the fish. These transmitters will last for a total of two years.
So cool, right??



This is what the acoustic transmitters look like!

title: Acoustic Telemetry
text:
How We Achieve This
To achieve this, we use acoustic receivers for long term, continuous tracking of aquatic animals! Since the receivers are always on, they are constantly recording temperature and signals from acoustic transmitters that are implanted within the walleye.



Acoustic Receiver


Then we use a specialized hydrophone to pick up transmitter signals in real time!



Mobile Hydrophone





VR100 processes tags in real time as the mobile hydrophone picks up the acoustic signals.

title: Acoustic Telemetry
section: How will I know if I catch a walleye that is part of this study?
text:
How will I know if I catch a walleye that is part of this study?
Wonderful question! All walleye that are tagged will have an orange loop tag between its first and second dorsal fin (see below)! This tag will have a phone number and loop tag number on it, so when you call it in, we can quickly identify the walleye!



This is what the loop tag will look like! Credit goes to the Wisconsin Cooperative Fishery Research Unit (WCFRU)

title: Projects
text:
Predicting House Prices with Machine Learning



Python


Machine Learning


Data Cleaning



This project involves using machine learning algorithms to predict house prices based on various features such as location, size, and amenities. It includes data cleaning, feature engineering, and model selection.



Jan 1, 2024














Customer Segmentation Using Clustering Techniques



R


Machine Learning


Clustering


Statistical Modelling



This project focuses on segmenting customers into different groups based on their purchasing behavior and demographics. It uses clustering algorithms like K-means and hierarchical clustering to identify distinct customer segments.



Apr 1, 2024














Visualizing Global CO2 Emissions



R


Data Visualization


Environmental Science



This project involves creating visualizations to show trends in global CO2 emissions over time. It includes data extraction from public databases, data cleaning, and using visualization libraries to create interactive charts and graphs.



Jul 1, 2024
